newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia, Malaysia push forward on island dispute.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia, Malaysia push forward on island dispute.

text.p: Indonesian and Malaysian leaders have agreed to speed up submitting a dispute over island groups to the International Court of Justice at The Hague, Indonesia's official Antara news agency reported on Saturday.
It said Indonesian President Suharto and Malaysia's Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad agreed that each would appoint an official of ministerial rank to speed along the process.
The two countries said in October they would submit the long-standing sovereignty dispute over the Sipadan and Ligitan islands off the Borneo coast to the international court.
Suharto and Mahathir met on Friday ahead of Saturday's informal summit of the seven-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

Antara also quoted Mahathir as telling Suharto that Malaysia had no objections to a proposal to build a line to pipe gas from Indonesia's Natuna field in the South China Sea to Thailand. The line would cross through Malaysian waters.

The two leaders also discussed a proposed bridge to link Sumatra island and the Malaysian mainland across the Straits of Malacca, and Mahathir agreed the project could materialise in the near future, Antara said.

The agency said Suharto and Vietnamese Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet agreed at a separate meeting to assign assistants to follow up on a previous accord to settle differences on part of their maritime border in the South China Sea.
ASEAN groups Indonesia, Malaysia, Vietnam, Thailand, Singapore, Brunei and the Philippines. Laos, Cambodia and Burma are attending the informal Jakarta summit for the first time as observers.
